findings.label: Suppliers with Current Red Flags
findings.detail: 2 current suppliers have Companies House compliance issues (historical payments were made before breaches started)

findings.label: Suspected Split Payments
findings.detail: 36 instances of 3+ payments just below approval thresholds in the same week
findings.context_note: Split payment detection has a high false-positive rate. Batch processing, staged invoices, and legitimate recurring payments can all trigger this pattern. FOI request for procurement approval chain recommended before drawing conclusions.

findings.label: Round-Number Payments (>£5K)
findings.detail: 686 exact round-number payments over £5,000 — may indicate estimates rather than invoiced amounts

findings.label: Year-End Spending Pattern
findings.detail: Building Cleaning Contract (External) spent 24.3x their monthly average in March (£4.4M above normal). Note: UK councils operate on April–March fiscal years, so elevated March spending is common as departments finalise annual budgets. Spikes above 3x warrant further scrutiny.
findings.context_note: March spending above the monthly average is expected for UK councils on April–March fiscal years. Compare against prior years' March figures for meaningful analysis.

findings.label: Rapid Payment Suppliers
findings.detail: 15 suppliers receive payments every <14 days on average. Top: Third Party (3.5 day avg, 1291 payments, £5.4M)

findings.label: Benford's Law Analysis
findings.detail: Digit distribution across 50,715 transactions shows χ²=5030.63 (statistically significant due to large sample size), but max digit deviation is only 4.9% — within the normal range for UK council spending patterns. No practical evidence of fabricated invoices.
findings.context_note: Chi-squared values on samples of 50,715+ transactions are naturally inflated and will almost always show statistical significance. The max digit deviation (4.9%) is a more meaningful indicator — deviations under 5% are typical for legitimate council spending.

findings.label: Second-Digit Benford's Anomaly
findings.detail: Second-digit distribution across 50,718 transactions shows p < 0.001 (highly significant). Digit 0 deviates 4.24% from Nigrini's expected distribution. Second-digit tests are more discriminating than first-digit for detecting round-number bias and fabricated invoices.
findings.context_note: Benford's second-digit analysis (Nigrini, 2012) uses chi-squared with 9 df. Critical values: 16.92 (p=0.05), 21.67 (p=0.01), 27.88 (p=0.001). n=50,718.

key_findings.title: 7 suppliers with clock-like payment regularity
key_findings.description: These suppliers receive payments at near-identical intervals (std dev <5 days). Top: Scc — every 4.0 days (1495 payments, £41.7M)

key_findings.title: NDORS TRAINER: 1975 transactions totalling £2.2M
key_findings.description: Averaging £1.1K per transaction — the council's most frequent supplier
